When PMs override technical expertise, organizations gamble with performance, security, and stability. Engineers have a duty to sound the alarm before â€œturn 3â€ becomes catastrophic.

title: When Intelligence Becomes a Trading Liability
partialText: The sharper the mind, the more elaborate the justification for staying wrong. Depth of thought becomes the mechanism of loss when it serves identity.

title: What Founders Need to Know Before Selling a Subscription Business
partialText: Thinking of selling your subscription startup? Learn how buyers value companies, what metrics matter, and why deals succeed or fall apart.

title: Why AI Agent Reliability Depends More on the Harness Than the Model
partialText: The APEX-Agents benchmark tested frontier models on real professional tasks (banking, consulting, law) Models score above 90% on coding puzzles and multiple-choice tests, then fail at the kind of work an analyst does on a Tuesday morning.

title: Context Rot Is Breaking Long AI Sessions
partialText: Bigger context windows help, but not enough. Learn how Recursive Language Models improve long-context reasoning with better scaling and stable performance.

title: New System Combines SLAM and Language Models for Online 3D Scene Mapping
partialText: This article surveys advances in mobile robot mapping and semantic scene understanding, highlighting the limitations of voxel grids, NeRFs, and closed-vocabulary systems. It introduces LEGS, a novel framework that combines online 3D Gaussian Splatting with language-aligned feature supervision, enabling robots to build real-time, open-vocabulary semantic maps and localize objects through natural language queries in large-scale environments.

title: How to Bootstrap Agent Evals with Synthetic Queries
partialText: Checking agent outputs isn't enough. The real failures hide in trajectories: which tools got called, in what order, with what inputs. This article walks through a pattern for building evals when you don't have production data yet. You define the dimensions your agent varies along, generate structured tuples across them, and turn those into natural-language test queries. Run them, read the traces, write down what broke. Those notes become goals that shape the next batch of queries. Repeat until the failures vanish.

title: Alignment Is Not About Values. Itâ€™s About Error Detection
partialText: Viability in alignment leads to a need for diverse, independent grounding, which diverse human flourishing optimizes.

title: Less Data, Same LLM Performance? UGA Says Yes
partialText: A recent paper from UGA shows you can match SOTA LLM performance with 2000 targeted samples instead of 300,000.

title: What the BBC Hot Dog Hoax Really Proved About AI
partialText: A BBC journalist tricked ChatGPT and Google with a fake blog post in 20 minutes.

title: Freemium or Not? How Subscription Startups Should Decide

title: Kubernetes Operators, Explained by a Production Engineer

title: The Illich Test for AI: Does Your Tool Make You Less Capable Without It?
partialText: Ivan Illich wrote Tools for Conviviality in 1973. It's the best framework for AI dependency nobody's using.

title: Claude Can Code. Can It Detect Backdoors in Binaries?
partialText: BinaryAudit benchmarks AI agents using Ghidra to find backdoors in compiled binaries of real open-source servers, proxies, and network infrastructure.

title: The Three Stages of AI Guardrails: From Filters to Enterprise Control Planes
partialText: Explore the 3 stages of AI guardrailsâ€”from LLM filters to agent authorization and multi-agent control planes for enterprise AI governance.

title: When to Automate Testing and When to Stay Manual
partialText: QA engineers and leads often face the same question: Should we automate this, or handle it manually? Thereâ€™s no single answer, and the right choice depends on context, stability, and value. I built a simple framework to guide these decisions.

title: Codex vs Factory vs Cursor: Does the Harness Really Matter for MVP Prototyping?

title: The Anti-Slop Playbook: How 38 Career Reports Proved Verified AI Content Wins
partialText: Across 38 career reports, a five-model consensus method shows why verificationâ€”not generationâ€”will define premium content in the AI era.

title: GPT-5.3 Codex Reviewed My .NET Data Access Library and Missed the Architecture
partialText: I asked GPT-5.3 Codex to review a reusable .NET data access library. It scored 46/100â€”and exposed the limits of AI architectural reasoning.
